[dot dot dot]
especially if she's a woman."
and then, in response to that tweet, a gaming journalist by the name Amanda Farough tweeted
"I said out loud, in my headset, "And this is why I hate playing these kinds of games. Thanks for the demo." (Emotionless face)
Then adding, "Now, granted, he though I was his "dev buddy" by accident, but holy shit was that a mistake.

and heres the thing that I guess isn't too shocking I feel like we have very much a culture of
people getting offended on someone elses behalf.

Tweeting, "No one is naming names publicly. This is being handled privately and gently.

that this is unprofessional behaviour. That's it."
Then adding, "Can't believe that I have to say this: I am not interested in hurting devs because

a reminder of how no to conduct a press demo."

One writing, "Creepy showing off at your son's birthday. Cover up you're a mum"

prudish and more conservative and the way they handle themselves, their dressing,
and, its almost like they're not seen as a person anymore, they are just this thing.
You're a mom, and people lock you into this box and they shame you if you go outside of that box.

it doesn't mean that you should all of the sudden become this other thing

and then later adding, "I'm Ellen now call me Ellen"
and then, someone responds to that. They take a screenshot of those tweets and then said
"h3h3 is transphobic"

and, in response to this and another tweet, a user wrote

then explaining, yes cutting your dick off in reaction to that would be excessive, but that is what the comedy is.

"Just because you are offended by a joke, doesn't mean that the joke was inherently offensive"
